Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Situation2: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was tightening the last bolt on the conveyor’s sensor panel. The production manager’s voice was tense—every minute the line was down cost the company money, and I was the only one who could fix it. I wiped sweat from my brow, already feeling the pressure of the ticking clock. Then, another message flashed on my screen. It was from my younger sister: “Can you call me? It’s urgent.” She never used that word lightly. We’d always promised to be there for each other, especially when things got tough. I could picture her sitting alone, waiting for me to pick up, needing her brother. But the hum of the silent machines around me reminded me of the team counting on my skills to get production moving again. My hands trembled as I stared at my phone, torn between the family bond I’d always cherished and the professional responsibility I couldn’t ignore.
